trans-unit.source: Build a Node.js web application using DocumentDB | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Build a Node.js web application using DocumentDB | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Microsoft Azure DocumentDB to store and access data from a Node.js Express web application hosted on Azure Websites.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Microsoft Azure DocumentDB to store and access data from a Node.js Express web application hosted on Azure Websites.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Build a Node.js web application using DocumentDB
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Build a Node.js web application using DocumentDB

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to use the Azure DocumentDB service to store and access data from a Node.js Express application hosted on Azure Websites.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to use the Azure DocumentDB service to store and access data from a Node.js Express application hosted on Azure Websites.

trans-unit.source: We recommend getting started by watching the following video, where we show you how to provision an Azure DocumentDB database account and store JSON documents in your Node.js application.
trans-unit.target: We recommend getting started by watching the following video, where we show you how to provision an Azure DocumentDB database account and store JSON documents in your Node.js application.

trans-unit.source: Then, return to this article, where you'll learn the answers to the following questions:
trans-unit.target: Then, return to this article, where you'll learn the answers to the following questions:

trans-unit.source: How do I work with DocumentDB using the documentdb npm module?
trans-unit.target: How do I work with DocumentDB using the documentdb npm module?

trans-unit.source: How do I deploy the web application to Azure Websites?
trans-unit.target: How do I deploy the web application to Azure Websites?

trans-unit.source: By following this tutorial, you will build a simple web-based
trans-unit.target: By following this tutorial, you will build a simple web-based

trans-unit.source: task-management application that allows creating, retrieving and
trans-unit.target: task-management application that allows creating, retrieving and

trans-unit.source: completing of tasks.
trans-unit.target: completing of tasks.

trans-unit.source: The tasks will be stored as JSON documents in Azure
trans-unit.target: The tasks will be stored as JSON documents in Azure

trans-unit.source: DocumentDB.
trans-unit.target: DocumentDB.

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Screen shot of the My Todo List application created in this tutorial</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Don't have time to complete the tutorial and just want to get the complete solution from GitHub?
trans-unit.target: Don't have time to complete the tutorial and just want to get the complete solution from GitHub?

trans-unit.source: Not a problem, get it <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Not a problem, get it <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: This tutorial assumes that you have some prior experience using Node.js and Azure Websites.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial assumes that you have some prior experience using Node.js and Azure Websites.

trans-unit.source: Before following the instructions in this article, you should ensure
trans-unit.target: Before following the instructions in this article, you should ensure

trans-unit.source: that you have the following:
trans-unit.target: that you have the following:

trans-unit.source: An active Azure account.
trans-unit.target: An active Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: For details, see <link><linkText>Azure Free Trial</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For details, see <link><linkText>Azure Free Trial</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Node.js[]</linkText><title></title></link> version v0.10.29 or higher.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Node.js[]</linkText><title></title></link> version v0.10.29 or higher.

trans-unit.source: Express generator (you can install this via npm install express-generator -g)
trans-unit.target: Express generator (you can install this via npm install express-generator -g)

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Git[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Git[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 1: Create a DocumentDB database account
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 1: Create a DocumentDB database account

trans-unit.source: Let's start by creating a DocumentDB account.
trans-unit.target: Let's start by creating a DocumentDB account.

trans-unit.source: If you already have an account, you can skip to <link><linkText>Step 2: Create a new Node.js application</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you already have an account, you can skip to <link><linkText>Step 2: Create a new Node.js application</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 2: Create a new Node.js application
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 2: Create a new Node.js application

trans-unit.source: Now let's create a basic Hello World Node.js project using the <link><linkText>Express</linkText><title></title></link> framework.
trans-unit.target: Now let's create a basic Hello World Node.js project using the <link><linkText>Express</linkText><title></title></link> framework.

trans-unit.source: Open your favorite terminal.
trans-unit.target: Open your favorite terminal.

trans-unit.source: Use the express generator to generate a new application called todo.
trans-unit.target: Use the express generator to generate a new application called todo.

trans-unit.source: Open your new todo directory and install dependencies.
trans-unit.target: Open your new todo directory and install dependencies.

trans-unit.source: Run your new application.
trans-unit.target: Run your new application.

trans-unit.source: You can you view your new application by navigating your browser to <link><linkText>http://localhost:3000</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can you view your new application by navigating your browser to <link><linkText>http://localhost:3000</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Screenshot of the Hello World application in a browser window</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Screenshot of the Hello World application in a browser window</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 3: Install additional modules
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 3: Install additional modules

trans-unit.source: The package.json file is one of the files created in the root of the
trans-unit.target: The package.json file is one of the files created in the root of the

trans-unit.source: project.
trans-unit.target: project.

trans-unit.source: This file contains a list of additional modules that are
trans-unit.target: This file contains a list of additional modules that are

trans-unit.source: required for your Node.js application.
trans-unit.target: required for your Node.js application.

trans-unit.source: Later, when you deploy this
trans-unit.target: Later, when you deploy this

trans-unit.source: application to an Azure Websites, this file is used to determine
trans-unit.target: application to an Azure Websites, this file is used to determine

trans-unit.source: which modules need to be installed on Azure to support your application.
trans-unit.target: which modules need to be installed on Azure to support your application.

trans-unit.source: We still need to install two more packages for this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: We still need to install two more packages for this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Back in the terminal, install the async module via npm.
trans-unit.target: Back in the terminal, install the async module via npm.

trans-unit.source: Install the documentdb module via npm.
trans-unit.target: Install the documentdb module via npm.

trans-unit.source: This is the module where all the DocumentDB magic happens.
trans-unit.target: This is the module where all the DocumentDB magic happens.

trans-unit.source: A quick check of the package.json file of the application should show the additional modules.
trans-unit.target: A quick check of the package.json file of the application should show the additional modules.

trans-unit.source: This file will tell Azure which packages to download and install when running your application.
trans-unit.target: This file will tell Azure which packages to download and install when running your application.

trans-unit.source: It should resemble the example below.
trans-unit.target: It should resemble the example below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Screenshot of the package.json tab</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Screenshot of the package.json tab</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This tells Node (and Azure later) that your application depends on these additional modules.
trans-unit.target: This tells Node (and Azure later) that your application depends on these additional modules.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 4: Using the DocumentDB service in a node application
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 4: Using the DocumentDB service in a node application

trans-unit.source: That takes care of all the initial setup and configuration, now let’s get down to why we’re here, and that’s to write some code using Azure DocumentDB.
trans-unit.target: That takes care of all the initial setup and configuration, now let’s get down to why we’re here, and that’s to write some code using Azure DocumentDB.

trans-unit.source: Create the model
trans-unit.target: Create the model

trans-unit.source: In the project directory, create a new directory named models.
trans-unit.target: In the project directory, create a new directory named models.

trans-unit.source: In the models directory, create a new file named taskDao.js.
trans-unit.target: In the models directory, create a new file named taskDao.js.

trans-unit.source: This file will contain the model for the tasks created by our application.
trans-unit.target: This file will contain the model for the tasks created by our application.

trans-unit.source: In the same models directory, create another new file named docdbUtils.js.
trans-unit.target: In the same models directory, create another new file named docdbUtils.js.

trans-unit.source: This file will contain some useful, reusable, code that we will use throughout our application.
trans-unit.target: This file will contain some useful, reusable, code that we will use throughout our application.

trans-unit.source: Copy the following code in to docdbUtils.js
trans-unit.target: Copy the following code in to docdbUtils.js

trans-unit.source: createCollection takes an optional requestOptions parameter that can be used to specify the Offer Type for the Collection.
trans-unit.target: createCollection takes an optional requestOptions parameter that can be used to specify the Offer Type for the Collection.

trans-unit.source: If no requestOptions.offerType value is supplied then the Collection will be created using the default Offer Type.
trans-unit.target: If no requestOptions.offerType value is supplied then the Collection will be created using the default Offer Type.

trans-unit.source: For more information on DocumentDB Offer Types please refer to <link><linkText>Performance levels in DocumentDB</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For more information on DocumentDB Offer Types please refer to <link><linkText>Performance levels in DocumentDB</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Save and close the docdbUtils.js file.
trans-unit.target: Save and close the docdbUtils.js file.

trans-unit.source: At the beginning of the taskDao.js file, add the following code to reference the DocumentDBClient and the docdbUtils.js we created above:
trans-unit.target: At the beginning of the taskDao.js file, add the following code to reference the DocumentDBClient and the docdbUtils.js we created above:

trans-unit.source: Next, you will add code to define and export the Task object.
trans-unit.target: Next, you will add code to define and export the Task object.

trans-unit.source: This is responsible for initializing our Task object and setting up the Database and Document Collection we will use.
trans-unit.target: This is responsible for initializing our Task object and setting up the Database and Document Collection we will use.

trans-unit.source: Next, add the following code to define additional methods on the Task object, which allow interactions with data stored in DocumentDB.
trans-unit.target: Next, add the following code to define additional methods on the Task object, which allow interactions with data stored in DocumentDB.

trans-unit.source: Save and close the taskDao.js file.
trans-unit.target: Save and close the taskDao.js file.

trans-unit.source: Create the controller
trans-unit.target: Create the controller

trans-unit.source: In the routes directory of your project, create a new file named tasklist.js.
trans-unit.target: In the routes directory of your project, create a new file named tasklist.js.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to tasklist.js.
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to tasklist.js.

trans-unit.source: This loads the DocumentDBClient and async modules, which are used by tasklist.js.
trans-unit.target: This loads the DocumentDBClient and async modules, which are used by tasklist.js.

trans-unit.source: This also defined the TaskList function, which is passed an instance of the Task object we defined earlier:
trans-unit.target: This also defined the TaskList function, which is passed an instance of the Task object we defined earlier:

trans-unit.source: Continue adding to the tasklist.js file by adding the methods used to showTasks, addTask, and completeTasks:
trans-unit.target: Continue adding to the tasklist.js file by adding the methods used to showTasks, addTask, and completeTasks:

trans-unit.source: Save and close the tasklist.js file.
trans-unit.target: Save and close the tasklist.js file.

trans-unit.source: Add config.js
trans-unit.target: Add config.js

trans-unit.source: In your project directory create a new file named config.js.
trans-unit.target: In your project directory create a new file named config.js.

trans-unit.source: Add the following to config.js.
trans-unit.target: Add the following to config.js.

trans-unit.source: This defines configuration settings and values needed for our application.
trans-unit.target: This defines configuration settings and values needed for our application.

trans-unit.source: In the config.js file, update the values of HOST and AUTH_KEY using the values found in the Keys blade of your DocumentDB account on the Microsoft Azure Preview portal:
trans-unit.target: In the config.js file, update the values of HOST and AUTH_KEY using the values found in the Keys blade of your DocumentDB account on the Microsoft Azure Preview portal:

trans-unit.source: Save and close the config.js file.
trans-unit.target: Save and close the config.js file.

trans-unit.source: Modify app.js
trans-unit.target: Modify app.js

trans-unit.source: In the project directory, open the app.js file.
trans-unit.target: In the project directory, open the app.js file.

trans-unit.source: This file was created earlier when the Express web application was created.
trans-unit.target: This file was created earlier when the Express web application was created.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to the top of app.js
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the top of app.js

trans-unit.source: This code defines the config file to be used, and proceeds to read values out of this file in to some variables we will use soon.
trans-unit.target: This code defines the config file to be used, and proceeds to read values out of this file in to some variables we will use soon.

trans-unit.source: Replace the following two lines in app.js file:
trans-unit.target: Replace the following two lines in app.js file:

trans-unit.source: with the following snippet:
trans-unit.target: with the following snippet:

trans-unit.source: These lines define a new instance of our TaskDao object, with a new connection to DocumentDB (using the values read from the config.js), initialize the task object and then bind form actions to methods on our TaskList controller.
trans-unit.target: These lines define a new instance of our TaskDao object, with a new connection to DocumentDB (using the values read from the config.js), initialize the task object and then bind form actions to methods on our TaskList controller.

trans-unit.source: Finally, save and close the app.js file, we're just about done.
trans-unit.target: Finally, save and close the app.js file, we're just about done.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 5: Build a user interface
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 5: Build a user interface

trans-unit.source: Now let’s turn our attention to building the user interface so a user can actually interact with our application.
trans-unit.target: Now let’s turn our attention to building the user interface so a user can actually interact with our application.

trans-unit.source: The Express application we created uses Jade as the view engine.
trans-unit.target: The Express application we created uses Jade as the view engine.

trans-unit.source: For more information on Jade please refer to <link><linkText>http://jade-lang.com/</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on Jade please refer to <link><linkText>http://jade-lang.com/</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The layout.jade file in the views directory is used as a global template for other .jade files.
trans-unit.target: The layout.jade file in the views directory is used as a global template for other .jade files.

trans-unit.source: In this step you will modify it to use <link><linkText>Twitter Bootstrap</linkText><title></title></link>, which is a toolkit that makes it easy to design a nice looking website.
trans-unit.target: In this step you will modify it to use <link><linkText>Twitter Bootstrap</linkText><title></title></link>, which is a toolkit that makes it easy to design a nice looking website.

trans-unit.source: Open the layout.jade file found in the views folder and replace the contents with the following;
trans-unit.target: Open the layout.jade file found in the views folder and replace the contents with the following;

trans-unit.source: This effectively tells the Jade engine to render some HTML for our application and creates a block called content where we can supply the layout for our content pages.
trans-unit.target: This effectively tells the Jade engine to render some HTML for our application and creates a block called content where we can supply the layout for our content pages.

trans-unit.source: Save and close this layout.jade file.
trans-unit.target: Save and close this layout.jade file.

trans-unit.source: Now open the index.jade file, the view that will be used by our application, and replace the content of the file with the following:
trans-unit.target: Now open the index.jade file, the view that will be used by our application, and replace the content of the file with the following:

trans-unit.source: This extends layout, and provides content for the content placeholder we saw in the layout.jade file earlier.
trans-unit.target: This extends layout, and provides content for the content placeholder we saw in the layout.jade file earlier.

trans-unit.source: In this layout we created two HTML forms.
trans-unit.target: In this layout we created two HTML forms.

trans-unit.source: The first form contains a table for our data and a button that allows us to update items by posting to /completetask method of our controller.
trans-unit.target: The first form contains a table for our data and a button that allows us to update items by posting to /completetask method of our controller.

trans-unit.source: The second form contains two input fields and a button that allows us to create a new item by posting to /addtask method of our controller.
trans-unit.target: The second form contains two input fields and a button that allows us to create a new item by posting to /addtask method of our controller.

trans-unit.source: This should be all that we need for our application to work.
trans-unit.target: This should be all that we need for our application to work.

trans-unit.source: Open the style.css file in public\stylesheets directory and replace the code with the following:
trans-unit.target: Open the style.css file in public\stylesheets directory and replace the code with the following:

trans-unit.source: Save and close this style.css file.
trans-unit.target: Save and close this style.css file.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 6: Run your application locally
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 6: Run your application locally

trans-unit.source: To test the application on your local machine, run npm start in a terminal to start your application, and launch a browser with a page that looks like the image below:
trans-unit.target: To test the application on your local machine, run npm start in a terminal to start your application, and launch a browser with a page that looks like the image below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Screenshot of the MyTodo List application in a browser window</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Screenshot of the MyTodo List application in a browser window</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Use the provided fields for Item, Item Name and Category to enter
trans-unit.target: Use the provided fields for Item, Item Name and Category to enter

trans-unit.source: information, and then click Add Item.
trans-unit.target: information, and then click Add Item.

trans-unit.source: The page should update to display the newly created item in the ToDo
trans-unit.target: The page should update to display the newly created item in the ToDo

trans-unit.source: list.
trans-unit.target: list.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Screenshot of the application with a new item in the ToDo list</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Screenshot of the application with a new item in the ToDo list</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To complete a task, simply check the checkbox in the Complete column,
trans-unit.target: To complete a task, simply check the checkbox in the Complete column,

trans-unit.source: and then click Update tasks.
trans-unit.target: and then click Update tasks.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 7: Deploy your application to Azure Websites
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 7: Deploy your application to Azure Websites

trans-unit.source: If you haven't already, enable a git repository for your Azure Website.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't already, enable a git repository for your Azure Website.

trans-unit.source: You can find instructions on how to do this <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can find instructions on how to do this <link><linkText>here</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Add your Azure Website as a git remote.
trans-unit.target: Add your Azure Website as a git remote.

trans-unit.source: Deploy by pushing to the remote.
trans-unit.target: Deploy by pushing to the remote.

trans-unit.source: In a few seconds, git will finish publishing your web
trans-unit.target: In a few seconds, git will finish publishing your web

trans-unit.source: application and launch a browser where you can see your handy work
trans-unit.target: application and launch a browser where you can see your handy work

trans-unit.source: running in Azure!
trans-unit.target: running in Azure!
